Introduction

Thrombocytopenia (measured platelet count <150,000/mm3) generally occurs due to decreased platelet production, increased platelet destruction, platelet sequestration, or platelet dilution, depending on the underlying pathophysiology and its associated clinical findings.

Pathophysiology

Normal platelet production and function



Platelets (thrombocytes) are cell fragments that initiate hemostasis following endothelial injury.  During the first phase of hemostasis (primary hemostasis), a platelet plug forms, as follows (

figure 1
):



  • Platelet adhesion (adherence):  Endothelial injury exposes connective tissue that contains von Willebrand factor (vWF), a protein that facilitates platelet adhesion to subendothelial collagen.
  • Platelet activation:  Adhesion induces platelet activation, a process in which the platelets undergo irreversible changes, developing a spiky shape and secreting:
    • ADP:  ADP induces further platelet activation.
    • Arachidonic acid:  This acid is converted to thromboxane A2 (TXA2), a substance that induces platelet aggregation.
  • Aggregation:  During platelet activation, glycoproteins IIb/IIIa (GPIIb/IIIa) receptors undergo a conformational change that allows the receptor to bind fibrinogen.  Fibrinogen binding causes platelets to aggregate, forming a platelet plug.


Platelet production (

figure 2
) (thrombopoiesis) occurs in the bone marrow and is regulated by thrombopoietin (TPO), a growth factor that stimulates proliferation, growth, and maturation of megakaryocytes (ie, hematopoietic cells that produce platelets).  Specifically, TPO induces endomitosis, in which a megakaryocyte progenitor cell replicates its DNA without subsequently dividing, resulting in a large cell (megakaryocyte) with folds of redundant cell membrane and polyploid nuclei (
image 1
).  The excess DNA (severalfold the amount of DNA in a normal diploid cell) allows for mass transcription of the intracellular proteins needed for platelet production.  In fact, thousands of platelets can bud off of a mature megakaryocyte and enter the circulation.  Newly formed platelets are large and more hemostatically active.  As they mature, they become smaller and less hemostatically active until they reach the end of their lifespan (7-10 days).

Platelet counts and thrombopoietin



Approximately one-third of a person's entire platelet mass is normally sequestered in the spleen.  The other two-thirds remain in the circulation (ie, measured platelet count), which is typically 150,000-450,000/mm3.  Total platelet mass is maintained within a stable, narrow range throughout a person's life.  If splenic enlargement (eg, from liver disease) develops, leading to the sequestration of even more platelets, there is a commensurate decrease in measured platelet count because total platelet mass is maintained at a stable value.



To maintain this stability, platelets must be continuously replaced.  TPO is unique in that it is constitutively produced by the liver and bone marrow; levels do not fluctuate, unlike with erythropoietin.  Both platelets and megakaryocyte progenitors contain TPO receptors, and, therefore, TPO activity is regulated by competition between these two.



  • Normally, most of the TPO gets cleared by binding platelets, leaving less free TPO to stimulate megakaryotic precursors in the marrow.  This maintains a baseline stable production of platelets.
  • Conversely, if total platelet mass decreases (eg, due to rapid use at hemorrhage sites), more free TPO is available to stimulate megakaryocytic progenitors, amplifying platelet production.

Four main mechanisms of thrombocytopenia



Various causes can contribute to thrombocytopenia (ie, measured platelet count <150,000/mm3).  The 4 main mechanisms include:



  • Decreased platelet production.
  • Increased platelet destruction.
  • Platelet sequestration.
  • Platelet dilution.

Decreased platelet production



There are several pathophysiologic mechanisms for decreased platelet production.

Bone marrow disorders



Bone marrow disorders can impair platelet production:



  • Infections (eg, parvovirus, cytomegalovirus, Epstein-Barr virus):  Viruses can cause transient (ie, weeks) bone marrow suppression, affecting one or more cell lines.
  • Bone marrow neoplasms:
    • Leukemia or metastatic neoplasms:  Neoplastic cells infiltrate the bone marrow, crowding hematopoietic stem cells.
    • Myelofibrosis:  Clonal megakaryocytes stimulate bone marrow fibrosis that impairs hematopoiesis.
    • Myelodysplastic syndrome:  Myeloid hematopoietic stem cell growth and differentiation are disrupted.
  • Aplastic anemia (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 1
    ):  Aplastic anemia is characterized by pancytopenia with hypocellular bone marrow, often due to immune-mediated destruction of hematopoietic stem cells.
  • Therapy (eg, chemotherapy, radiation):  Cytotoxic drugs and radiation can damage proliferating megakaryocytes.  The reduction in platelet production is dose dependent, with recovery possible after completion of therapy.
  • Nutritional deficiencies (eg, vitamin B12, folate):  Vitamin B12 and folate are necessary for DNA synthesis in megakaryocytes.  Deficiency in either results in ineffective platelet production and associated macrocytic anemia.  Megaloblastic changes (eg, hypersegmented neutrophils) are often evident on a bone marrow biopsy in these cases.

Inherited platelet disorders



The genetic conditions that affect thrombopoiesis include:



  • Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome:  This X-linked disorder is associated with small platelets, eczema, and immunodeficiency.
  • Bernard-Soulier syndrome:  This syndrome is associated with giant platelets.
  • Inherited bone marrow failure syndromes (eg, Fanconi anemia).


Overall, these conditions are rare and may impair platelet function.

Liver disease



Because TPO is produced primarily by the liver, patients with chronic liver disease can also develop thrombocytopenia.

Increased platelet destruction



Several pathophysiologic mechanisms lead to the rapid destruction of circulating platelets.  These conditions are characterized by compensatory megakaryocyte expansion and platelet production.

Immune-mediated destruction



  • Immune thrombocytopenia purpura (ITP) (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 2
    ):  ITP is characterized by the formation of autoantibodies against platelet surface glycoproteins (eg, GPIIb/IIIa).  The antibody-coated platelets are cleared by macrophages, primarily in the spleen.  ITP can occur as primary or secondary to underlying conditions (eg, systemic lupus erythematosus, HIV, hepatitis C).
  • Drug-induced immune thrombocytopenia:  Certain drugs (eg, quinine, sulfonamides, antiepileptics) can lead to the formation of autoantibodies against platelets, causing rapid platelet destruction.  This mechanism of active destruction is unlike chemotherapy-induced thrombocytopenia, which impairs platelet production.
  • Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 3
    ):  Type 2 HIT is characterized by the formation of autoantibodies against the complex of heparin and platelet factor 4 (
    figure 3
    ) in patients with prior exposure to heparin.  These immune complexes not only lead to platelet destruction, but also cause platelet activation, resulting in paradoxical thrombosis despite low platelet counts.  Diagnosis is confirmed with serotonin release assays.  In untreated cases, the risk for thrombotic events, including venous and arterial thrombosis, is high.  A milder, nonâ€“immune-mediated form of HIT also exists (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 4
    ).

Nonâ€“immune-mediated destruction



  • Thrombotic microangiopathies (eg, thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura [TTP], hemolytic uremic syndrome [HUS]):  Thrombotic microangiopathies are characterized by widespread microvascular thrombosis that leads to accelerated platelet consumption.  TTP is classically associated with deficient ADAMTS13, an enzyme that cleaves vWF multimers.  Without ADAMTS13, ultra-large vWF multimers cause platelet aggregation and microvascular thrombosis.  HUS, typically seen in children after infection with Shiga toxinâ€“producing Escherichia coli (
    figure 4
    ), results in similar microangiopathic destruction.
  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 5
    ):  In DIC, systemic activation of the coagulation cascade leads to widespread microthrombi formation and platelet consumption, leading to thrombocytopenia.  DIC can occur secondary to sepsis, trauma, or malignancy.  DIC is characterized by both thrombosis and bleeding due to the depletion of clotting factors and platelets.
  • Mechanical destruction (eg, mechanical heart valves, extracorporeal circulation):  Physical forces from mechanical heart valves or extracorporeal circuits, such as during cardiopulmonary bypass, can shear platelets, leading to their premature destruction and thrombocytopenia.

Platelet sequestration



Approximately one-third of all platelets are normally sequestered in the spleen.  Some conditions can cause additional platelet sequestration.

Portal hypertension



Portal hypertension (commonly seen in advanced liver disease) (

figure 5
) leads to splenic congestion and platelet sequestration (hypersplenism).  Other blood cells may also be trapped, causing additional cytopenias.

Lymphoproliferative disorders



Lymphoproliferative disorders (eg, acute lymphoblastic leukemia, Hodgkin lymphoma) may be associated with infiltration of the spleen by malignant lymphoid cells, which can cause splenomegaly and platelet sequestration.



Beyond the spleen, platelets can be sequestered in the placenta during pregnancy.  Because platelet sequestration involves the redistribution of circulating platelets, these patients generally do not have increased bleeding risk.

Platelet dilution



Excess plasma volume can cause dilutional thrombocytopenia.  Fluid resuscitation is the most common cause, but other etiologies include:



  • Gestational thrombocytopenia:  Gestational thrombocytopenia is a benign condition that occurs in 5%-10% of pregnancies, likely due to physiologic plasma volume expansion during pregnancy.  Gestational thrombocytopenia is most commonly diagnosed in the third trimester but can occur earlier.  Patients have no bruising or bleeding, and peripheral blood smear is unremarkable.  Platelet count typically normalizes within 6 weeks of delivery without intervention.
  • Postoperative thrombocytopenia:  Postoperative thrombocytopenia can occur a few days after surgery, likely due to fluid shifts and platelet consumption.

Clinical presentation



Patients with only mild thrombocytopenia are usually asymptomatic.  In these cases, thrombocytopenia is often an incidental finding on laboratory testing obtained for other reasons.  Patients with moderate or severe thrombocytopenia are more likely to present with mucosal (eg, epistaxis) and/or cutaneous (eg, petechiae (

image 2
), ecchymoses (
image 3
)) bleeding.  Female patients may report prolonged and/or heavy menstrual bleeding.  In severe cases, patients may present with life-threatening intracranial hemorrhage.  Depending on the underlying cause, additional clinical findings (eg, fever, bone pain) may be present.  Rarely, patients with thrombocytopenia can develop paradoxical thrombosis (eg, HIT, paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria).  The details of these conditions are discussed more in their respective articles.

Differential diagnosis

Pseudothrombocytopenia



Pseudothrombocytopenia is a low platelet count due to laboratory errors (eg, improper processing).  Samples obtained for complete blood counts are normally drawn in an anticoagulant tube (usually ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid [EDTA], which best preserves cell components and morphology).  However, EDTA can expose certain antigens on platelets, causing them to aggregate within the tube, resulting in a falsely low platelet count.  Large clumps of platelets can be visualized on peripheral smear (

image 4
).  A normal platelet count in a specimen collected in a non-EDTA anticoagulant tube (eg, sodium citrate) confirms the diagnosis.  Patients with pseudothrombocytopenia have normal platelet counts and therefore are asymptomatic and do not require intervention or monitoring.

Other disorders of primary hemostasis



Other disorders of primary hemostasis can present with abnormal bleeding, similar to thrombocytopenia.  These conditions include:



  • Collagen disorders:  Because contact with subendothelial collagen is an important step in primary hemostasis, patients with underlying collagen disorders (eg, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, osteogenesis imperfecta) can present with easy bruising (
    image 5
    ).  Other physical examination findings, including skin hyperextensibility (
    image 6
    in Ehlers-Danlos syndrome and blue sclerae (
    image 7
    ) in osteogenesis imperfecta, may be consistent with these conditions.
  • Platelet function disorder (eg, Glanzman thrombasthenia):  Patients with platelet function disorders have abnormal bleeding despite normal platelet counts and coagulation testing.  In some cases, concurrent thrombocytopenia (eg, Bernard-Soulier syndrome) can lead to abnormal bleeding that is disproportionate (ie, more severe) to the degree of thrombocytopenia.  In these cases, platelet dysfunction should be suspected.  Additional platelet function testing (eg, platelet aggregometry) can be used to evaluate for these conditions.
  • von Willebrand disease (vWD):  vWD is the most common inherited bleeding disorder.  vWF is essential for the formation of the primary platelet plug.  Because platelet production and consumption are unaffected, the platelet count in vWD is typically normal.

Plasma coagulation disorders (eg, factor VIII deficiency)



Disorders of secondary hemostasis can also present with abnormal bleeding, but the pattern tends to be deep tissue bleeding (eg, muscular, intraarticular) with significant deep purpura.  Superficial petechiae are uncommon in coagulation disorders.

Evaluation and diagnosis



The work-up for thrombocytopenia typically involves a history and physical examination, as well as laboratory evaluation, including peripheral smear evaluation.

Detailed history



  • Bleeding history (eg, bruising with minimal trauma, persistent bleeding with minor wounds, prolonged menses).
  • Family history of bleeding disorders.
  • History of thrombocytopenia (prior platelet counts can help distinguish whether this is an acute vs a chronic condition).
  • Exposures (eg, medications [eg, antiepileptic drugs, antibiotics], recent infections).
  • Dietary history to suggest a nutritional deficiency.
  • Systemic symptoms to suggest an underlying medical condition (eg, malignancy, autoimmune disorder).

Physical examination



  • Extent of bleeding (eg, presence of purpura on mucosal surfaces or hematuria can be associated with more extensive/severe hemorrhage).
  • Presence of splenomegaly/hepatomegaly to suggest sequestration as a cause.
  • Presence of lymphadenopathy (suggesting malignancy or infection).
  • Signs suggesting other inherited conditions (eg, short stature, eczema to suggest Wiskottâ€“Aldrich syndrome, limb abnormalities associated with inherited bone marrow failure syndromes).

Laboratory evaluation



  • Complete blood count with differential and peripheral smear evaluation.
    • Evaluates the degree of thrombocytopenia, as follows:
      • Mild:  100,000-149,000/mm3.
      • Moderate:  50,000-99,000/mm3.
      • Severe:  <50,000/mm3.
    • Determines whether other cell lines are affected.  Pancytopenia is more suggestive of bone marrow failure or splenic sequestration.  Concurrent leukocytosis suggests an inflammatory cause (eg, infection) or malignancy.
  • Peripheral smear review:
    • Determines whether thrombocytopenia is due to laboratory error by assessing for platelet clumps, which are typically present at the edge of the smear.  Peripheral smear is particularly important when the reported platelet count is inconsistent with the clinical presentation.
    • Determines platelet size (normally about one-fourth the diameter of a red blood cell [RBC]), which can also be measured by the mean platelet volume:
      • Large platelets:  Because platelets normally get smaller as they age, an increased proportion of large platelets is suggestive of a destructive condition (eg, ITP) with compensatory thrombopoiesis.  Uniformly giant platelets (ie, larger than the diameter of a normal RBC) (
        image 8
        ) are associated with certain inherited platelet disorders (eg, Bernard-Soulier syndrome).
      • Small platelets:  Uniformly small platelets are associated with certain inherited platelet disorders (eg, Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome).
    • Additional helpful findings may include the presence of schistocytes (
      image 9
      ), suggesting thrombotic microangiopathy; blast cells (
      image 10
      ), suggesting leukemia; atypical (ie, reactive) lymphocytes (
      image 11
      ), suggesting infectious mononucleosis; and hypersegmented neutrophils (
      image 12
      ), suggesting nutritional deficiencies.


Depending on these results, additional laboratory testing, including genetic testing, viral testing, and additional hematologic testing (eg, reticulocyte count, direct antiglobulin [Coombs] test, coagulation testing, serotonin assay) may be necessary.  Bone marrow evaluation is generally not necessary for isolated thrombocytopenia but may be indicated if there is concern for bone marrow involvement (eg, pancytopenia without a clear etiology, blasts on peripheral smear).

Management



The management of thrombocytopenia involves:



  • Reduce the risk for bleeding:
    • Activity restrictions:  Avoiding contact sports and other activities that increase the patient's risk for injury.
    • Medication restrictions:  Avoiding drugs that can affect platelet function (eg, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs).
  • Transfuse only if necessary:  Because of the short lifespan of platelets, transfusion is only a temporary solution.  In some conditions (eg, ITP), the transfused platelets are immediately tagged for splenic removal by circulating immunoglobulins.  In addition, transfusion increases the risk for autoantibody formation in cases of frequent exposure.  These factors should be considered when determining whether to transfuse.  Indications to transfuse include:
    • Preoperative planning:  Platelet count should be >50,000/mm3 for minor procedures (eg, skin biopsy) and >100,000/mm3 for high-risk procedures (eg, neurosurgery).
    • Prevention of spontaneous hemorrhage in a high-risk patient (eg, bone marrow suppression from recent chemotherapy).
    • Significant active bleeding.
  • Use TPO receptor agonists, which can increase the platelet count in patients with thrombocytopenia due to low TPO (eg, liver dysfunction).
  • Treat the underlying condition (eg, cause of DIC).

Prognosis



Overall, the prognosis for thrombocytopenia is favorable.  Life-threatening hemorrhage is the primary cause of morbidity and mortality, especially in patients with:



  • Severe thrombocytopenia (ie, <20,000/mm3).
  • Certain underlying conditions (eg, inherited platelet disorders that affect their quantity and quality, concurrent coagulopathies).


ITP is associated with relatively less risk for bleeding because most of the circulating platelets are younger and therefore more hemostatically active.  In contrast, in conditions associated with impaired platelet production, the circulating platelets are older and less hemostatically active, leading to an increased risk for bleeding.

Summary



Thrombocytopenia (measured platelet count <150,000/mm3) generally occurs due to decreased platelet production, increased platelet destruction, platelet sequestration, or platelet dilution (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 6
).  Identifying the cause and overall risk for bleeding is the key for optimizing patient management and preventing life-threatening hemorrhage.
